docs.snippet: TANO is a growing handbag-and-shoe chain with franchised branches in Ridgefield, Westport, Danbury and Greenwich. The uniform origin of the handbags  at Tano of Madrid's leather factory is reflected in the normal 20 percent discounts, compared with...
docs.lead_paragraph: TANO is a growing handbag-and-shoe chain with franchised branches in Ridgefield, Westport, Danbury and Greenwich. The uniform origin of the handbags at Tano of Madrid's leather factory is reflected in the normal 20 percent discounts, compared with prices at other stores, with an additional 25 to 50 percent taken off now during the clearance sale continuing into August. New fall handbags are to go on sale tomorrow at the 20 percent discount. The four-year-old Greenwich branch at 83 Greenwich Avenue carries 35 styles of Spanish-made shoes, along with wares from Argentina, Italy, Uruguay, Sweden and Korea - some at retail prices, some discounted - with prices still lower during these seasonal sales. Branches differ more in types of footwear stocked than in the range of Tano handbags, according to Anthony Di Capua, manager.

headline.main: Handbags and Shoes At a Discount

docs.snippet: Peru returned to democratic government today, after 12 years of military rule, with the inauguration of President Fernando Belaunde Terry for a five-year term.         Addressing a joint session of Congress, Mr. Belaunde said the return to...
docs.lead_paragraph: Peru returned to democratic government today, after 12 years of military rule, with the inauguration of President Fernando Belaunde Terry for a five-year term. Addressing a joint session of Congress, Mr. Belaunde said the return to constitutional rule meant ''the full exercise, from this moment, of human rights and freedom of the press.''

headline.main: CIVILIAN PRESIDENT TAKES OFFICE IN PERU

docs.lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 5--The military Government of Bolivia is struggling to circumvent an American-led ban on economic aid by making financial deals with neighboring military dictatorships and a few other countries that have formally recognized it.
docs.abstract: is struggling to circumvent American-led ban on economic aid by making financial deals with neighboring military dictatorships and few other countries that have formally recognized it; only nations to have granted formal recognition are Argentina, Brazil, Egypt, Israel, Taiwan, Paraguay, Uruguay and South Africa; Soviet Union is believed to have offered some assistance; Fernando Knaudt Baner, importer and supporter of Garcia Meza, Fernando Bedoya Ballivian, head of Banco Nacional de Bolivia, comment; illustration of Information Min Fernando Palacios (M)

headline.main: Bolivia Regime Looks to Its Friends to Help Foil U.S.; Ways to Survive Noted U.S. Urged to Hold Fast Projects Called 'Very Important'

byline.original: By WARREN HOGE Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: The military Government of Bolivia is struggling to circumvent an American-led ban on economic aid by making financial deals with neighboring military dictatorships and a few other countries that have formally recognized it.         Bolivia is...
docs.lead_paragraph: The military Government of Bolivia is struggling to circumvent an American-led ban on economic aid by making financial deals with neighboring military dictatorships and a few other countries that have formally recognized it. Bolivia is dependent on outside assistance and investment, and its economy was already in crisis before the United States, Venezuela and several European countries suspended their aid programs in protest over the seizure of power by Gen. Luis Garcia Meza Tejada. The coup July 17 prevented Hernan Siles Suazo, the leftist winner of elections June 29, from assuming office as scheduled tomorrow on Bolivia's Independence Day.

headline.main: BOLIVIA REGIME LOOKS TO ITS FRIENDS TO HELP FOIL U.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 5 (AP)-- Gene Mayer, the top-seeded player, scored an easy first-round victory today but the top-seeded woman, Chris Evert Lloyd, struggled to extend her victory streak to 27 in the United States open clay-court tennis championships.

headline.main: Mrs. Lloyd Struggles but Continues Streak; Easy Start Mrs. Lloyd Struggles But Continues Streak

docs.snippet: Gene Mayer, the top-seeded player, scored an easy first-round victory today but the top-seeded woman, Chris Evert Lloyd, struggled to extend her victory streak to 27 in the United States open clay-court tennis championships.         Mrs. Lloyd, the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gene Mayer, the top-seeded player, scored an easy first-round victory today but the top-seeded woman, Chris Evert Lloyd, struggled to extend her victory streak to 27 in the United States open clay-court tennis championships. Mrs. Lloyd, the defending champion who has won this event five times, ousted Joanne Russell, 6-4, 6-4. Mayer needed 48 minutes to eliminate Leif Shiras, 6-1, 6-0, in a match halted for more than a hour by rain at the Indianapolis Sports Center.

headline.main: MRS. LLOYD STRUGGLES BUT CONTINUES STREAK
